docs.lead_paragraph: MILFORD, N.H.  George Brown, 50, the owner of Arthur's barber shop on the Oval in this picturesque New England town, said he "breathed a sigh of relief" whenScott Brown was elected to the Senate last week in neighboring Massachusetts.

headline.main: In New Hampshire, an Angry Tide Swells

docs.abstract: Anger in New Hampshire is rooted in a combination of factors, including fear over the proposed health care legislation, anxiety about the flailing economy and distrust of an overreaching government.
docs.snippet: Anger in New Hampshire is rooted in a combination of factors, including fear over the proposed health care legislation, anxiety about the flailing economy and distrust of an overreaching government.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Democrats seem not just helpless to deal with the crisis, but completely out of touch with the hardships that have fallen on so many Americans.
docs.snippet: The Democrats seem not just helpless to deal with the crisis, but completely out of touch with the hardships that have fallen on so many Americans.

docs.lead_paragraph: The ordinarily cool and cerebral President Obama sounded unusually defiant and vowed to move forward on a health care overhaul and new restrictions on banks.

headline.main: Obama, With Defiant Tone, Vows to Push Agenda

docs.lead_paragraph: Medical costs for an autistic child can run as much as $72,000 a year and insurance does not cover many treatments.

headline.seo: A Road Map to Help Parents Deal With the Financial Burden of Autism

docs.lead_paragraph: Here's what has not changed about the health care system in America. According to the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office, by 2019 there will be 54 million people in the United States without health insurance. The chief actuary of the federal Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services says it will be even worse: 57 million people without insurance.

headline.kicker: PRESCRIPTIONS | MAKING SENSE OF THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE

docs.abstract: Results of special election in Massachusetts may have permanently shifted health care debate, but inescapable reality facing Democrats and Republicans is that steep rise in cost of health care is single biggest threat to nation's economic security that policy makers can predict and, to some degree, control (M)
docs.snippet: Here's what has not changed about the health care system in America.     According to the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office, by 2019 there will be 54 million people in the United States without health insurance. The chief actuary of the federal...

docs.lead_paragraph: Forty-seven health policy experts sent a letter on Friday to the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, and the chairmen of three key House committees urging the House to adopt the Senate's health care legislation. Signers included economists and political scientists from across the liberal and moderate political spectrum who have been involved in the legislative effort.

docs.lead_paragraph: McCain-Feingold, that Quixotic attempt to turn money and politics into oil and water, was lanced by the Supreme Court on Thursday in a 5-4 decision based on the idea, espoused by Justice Anthony Kennedy, that "If the First Amendment has any force, it prohibits Congress from fining or jailing citizens, or associations of citizens, for simply engaging in political speech." To some extent, most of us would agree on the "citizens" point -- it's that "associations" bit that's the fly in the ointment for many.

headline.main: Put Your Money Where Your Politics Are

docs.abstract: In overturning McCain-Feingold, did the Supreme Court honor the First Amendment or hand our democracy over to the highest bidder?
docs.snippet: In overturning McCain-Feingold, did the Supreme Court honor the First Amendment or hand our democracy over to the highest bidder?

headline.main: Obama Vows to Keep Fighting for Health Care Overhaul

docs.abstract: "We can't keep on putting this off," the president told a crowd in Elyria, Ohio.
docs.snippet: "We can't keep on putting this off," the president told a crowd in Elyria, Ohio.

docs.lead_paragraph: In the latest poll from the Kaiser Family Foundation, Americans are evenly divided over the "health reform proposals being discussed in Congress," a finding echoed in other recent national polls.

headline.main: Poll: Americans Support Aspects of Health Care Legislation

docs.abstract: While Americans were evenly divided over health care legislation generally, a new poll found, majorities approved when certain elements were described.
docs.snippet: While Americans were evenly divided over health care legislation generally, a new poll found, majorities approved when certain elements were described.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama's plan to rein in big banks and their ability to make risky bets may seem to hark back to the days when commercial banking and investment banking were separated by the Depression-era Glass-Steagall Act. But the so-called Volcker Rule, as Mr. Obama's proposal is known, does not go as far as Glass-Steagall in that it would allow commercial banks to retain some investment banking activities, like underwriting securities and trading on behalf of clients.

headline.main: Yearning for Glass-Steagall on Capitol Hill

docs.abstract: Some lawmakers in Washington want to alter President Obama's banking regulation proposal to look more like Glass-Steagall, a move that if successful would have a profound impact on the face of Wall Street.
docs.snippet: Some lawmakers in Washington want to alter President Obama's banking regulation proposal to look more like Glass-Steagall, a move that if successful would have a profound impact on the face of Wall Street.
